statement.tex: %text $336$ apples are distributed equally amongst a certain number of students. Had there been $6$ more students, each would have got one apple less. How many students are there? %

step.context: %text Does the following equation correctly account for the difference in each person's share? %
step.reason: %text If $336$ apples were to be distributed equally among $N$ people, each person's share would be $\dfrac{336}{N}$ If there were $6$ more people, each person's share would decrease by $1$ to $\dfrac{336}{N+6}$ % \therefore 1=\dfrac{336}{N}-\dfrac{336}{N+6}

\begin{align} & 1=\dfrac{336}{N}-\dfrac{336}{N+6} \\ \implies & 1=336\left(\dfrac{1}{N}-\dfrac{1}{N+6}\right) \\ \implies & N(N+6)=336 \left(N+6-N \right) \\ \implies & N^2+6N-2016=0 \\ \implies & N^2-42N+48N-2016=0 \\ \implies & N(N-42)+48(N-48)=0 \\ \implies & N=42, N=-48 \end{align} \\ %text Since there cannot be negative number of people therefore, $N=42$ %
